ws.rocket.config

Class ConfigModel<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • ws.rocket.config.ConfigModel<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - The target type that will hold the read configuration.

    public final class ConfigModel<T>
extends Object
    Configuration model holds the description of what structure a configuration file may have, how to parse it, and where to write the configuration settings/values (in a bean object).

    The configuration files consist of sections with name (in square brackets) and configuration lines per section. A SectionReader attempts to interpret each non-blank line in corresponding section, tries to convert it into desired runtime type and stores it in its buffer. Typically a section settings line either contains a full value or a key-value pair (separated by equals-sign). Therefore, the values of a section are stored in a list or map (in the reader object).

    Once a section ends in the configuration file, the parsed data is immediately stored in the configuration bean. This is handled by SectionWriter that uses BeanWriter for writing data to target bean.

    All in all, configuration consists of sections with unique names. Their order must match in files (although the file may omit some of them). Besides name, each section also has a section reader (interprets lines) and a section writer (knows where to store collected information in the configuration data bean).

    Configuration model class serves three purposes:

    1. describes the expected configuration format
    2. enables elementary validation of the constructed model
    3. enables configuration file parsing
    Author:
    Martti Tamm

      static class  ConfigModel.ConfigModelBuilder<T>
      Configuration model builder defines the language for describing a configuration file sections and their content parsing methods.

      • parse

        public T parse(InputStream input)
        throws ConfigException
        Parses the input stream expecting sections with configuration settings. Each section will be parsed as defined in this model. Serious conflicts in stream can eventually trigger ConfigException, while minor conflicts (bad setting lines) might just be logged as warnings.

        The sections in the configuration stream must be ordered the same way as in this model, however, sections in the stream may omit some of those in the model. Duplicate sections or bad section names will raise ConfigException.

        Parameters:
        input - Configuration stream. When null then ConfigException will be raised.
        Returns:
        A new instance of configuration object with data set as defined in the stream.
        Throws:
        ConfigException - Contains error and possibly also warning messages from parsing the stream.

      • describeTo

        public void describeTo(PrintStream out)
        Provides textual representation of the current model setup and writes it to the provided stream.

        Applications might use this to enlist what settings are available and how a configuration file should look like. The output of this method should not be considered as valid setup, nor is it guaranteed to be always syntactically correct.

        Parameters:
        out - The stream where to write.
        See Also:
        toString()

        Provides textual representation of the current model setup and returns it as string.
